canonical_explanation.text: Geometric constructions involve creating precise geometric figures using only a compass and straightedge (ruler without measurements). Key constructions for ICSE Class 10 include: (1) Construction of tangents to a circle from an external point - utilizing the property that a tangent is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact; (2) Construction of a circumscribed circle (circumcircle) - the circle passing through all vertices of a polygon, found using perpendicular bisectors of sides that intersect at the circumcenter; (3) Construction of an inscribed circle (incircle) - the circle tangent to all sides of a polygon, found using angle bisectors that intersect at the incenter; (4) Combined constructions based on given conditions - requiring multiple construction techniques. All constructions must be performed using only a ruler and compass, following precise geometric principles.
rules: A tangent to a circle is perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency
From an external point, exactly two tangents can be drawn to a circle, and they are equal in length
The circumcenter of a triangle is the point of intersection of perpendicular bisectors of its sides
The circumcircle passes through all three vertices of a triangle
The incenter of a triangle is the point of intersection of angle bisectors
The incircle is tangent to all three sides of the triangle
Only ruler (straightedge) and compass are permitted in geometric constructions
Construction steps must follow logical geometric principles
Tangent from external point construction uses the midpoint of the line joining the external point and center
Perpendicular bisectors are used to find the circumcenter

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps in correct order for constructing tangents to a circle from an external point P:
ordering_items: Mark intersection points T1 and T2 of the two circles as points of tangency
Join external point P to center O of the given circle
Find the midpoint M of line segment PO
Draw a circle with center M and radius equal to MO (or MP)
Draw lines PT1 and PT2 which are the required tangents
correct_answer: Join external point P to center O of the given circle
Find the midpoint M of line segment PO
Draw a circle with center M and radius equal to MO (or MP)
Mark intersection points T1 and T2 of the two circles as points of tangency
Draw lines PT1 and PT2 which are the required tangents
questions.hint: Start by connecting the external point to the circle's center.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps in correct order for constructing the circumcircle of triangle ABC:

Draw perpendicular bisector of side AB
Draw triangle ABC with given measurements

Draw perpendicular bisector of side BC
correct_answer: Draw triangle ABC with given measurements
Draw perpendicular bisector of side AB
Draw perpendicular bisector of side BC
Mark the intersection point of the two perpendicular bisectors as O (circumcenter)
With center O and radius OA (or OB or OC), draw the circumcircle

correct_answer: Draw the angle bisector of angle A
Draw the angle bisector of angle B

Draw a perpendicular from I to any side to find the inradius
With center I and the inradius, draw the incircle

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps for constructing a perpendicular bisector of line segment AB:
ordering_items: Draw arcs on both sides of AB from point A with radius greater than half of AB
Join the two intersection points to get the perpendicular bisector
With the same radius, draw arcs from point B intersecting previous arcs
Mark the intersection points of arcs on both sides of AB
Draw line segment AB
correct_answer: Draw line segment AB
Draw arcs on both sides of AB from point A with radius greater than half of AB
With the same radius, draw arcs from point B intersecting previous arcs
Mark the intersection points of arcs on both sides of AB
Join the two intersection points to get the perpendicular bisector
questions.hint: The construction requires arcs from both endpoints with equal radii.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps for constructing an angle bisector of angle ABC:
ordering_items: Join point B to point P to get the angle bisector
With B as center and suitable radius, draw an arc cutting BA at point D and BC at point E
Mark the intersection point of these two arcs as P
With D as center and any convenient radius, draw an arc in the interior of angle ABC
With E as center and the same radius, draw another arc intersecting the previous arc
correct_answer: With B as center and suitable radius, draw an arc cutting BA at point D and BC at point E
With D as center and any convenient radius, draw an arc in the interior of angle ABC
With E as center and the same radius, draw another arc intersecting the previous arc
Mark the intersection point of these two arcs as P
Join point B to point P to get the angle bisector
questions.hint: Begin with an arc from the angle's vertex.
